question.title: Count Nice Pairs in an Array
question.content:
You are given an array nums that consists of non-negative integers. Let us define rev(x) as the reverse of the non-negative integer x. For example, rev(123) = 321, and rev(120) = 21. A pair of indices (i, j) is nice if it satisfies all of the following conditions:

  • 0 <= i < j < nums.length
  • nums[i] + rev(nums[j]) == nums[j] + rev(nums[i])

Return the number of nice pairs of indices. Since that number can be too large, return it modulo 109 + 7.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [42,11,1,97]
Output: 2
Explanation: The two pairs are:
 - (0,3) : 42 + rev(97) = 42 + 79 = 121, 97 + rev(42) = 97 + 24 = 121.
 - (1,2) : 11 + rev(1) = 11 + 1 = 12, 1 + rev(11) = 1 + 11 = 12.

Example 2:

Input: nums = [13,10,35,24,76]
Output: 4

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= nums.length <= 105
  • 0 <= nums[i] <= 109

  def count_nice_pairs(nums) do

hints: The condition can be rearranged to (nums[i] - rev(nums[i])) == (nums[j] - rev(nums[j])).
Transform each nums[i] into (nums[i] - rev(nums[i])). Then, count the number of (i, j) pairs that have equal values.

Keep a map storing the frequencies of values that you have seen so far. For each i, check if nums[i] is in the map. If it is, then add that count to the overall count. Then, increment the frequency of nums[i].

struct hash_entry {
    int id;            /* we'll use this field as the key */
    char name[10];

struct hash_entry *users = NULL;

void add_user(struct hash_entry *s) {
    HASH_ADD_INT(users, id, s);
}

2. Looking up an item in a hash: 

struct hash_entry *find_user(int user_id) {
    struct hash_entry *s;
    HASH_FIND_INT(users, &user_id, s);
    return s;
}

void delete_user(struct hash_entry *user) {

}
